LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  The Republic of the Philippines 
 
The Proposal  Support  to  the  Government  for  its  Second  Nonbank  Financial 
Governance (SNFG) Program through a program loan of $150 million, 
and technical assistance (TA) of $500,000 for support for the nonbank 
financial sector. 
 
Rationale  Despite recent reforms in the nonbank financial (NBF) sector, remains 
  small, underdeveloped, and fragmented. It is highly segmented due to 
legal, regulatory, and institutional constraints, and investment products 
of a similar nature are subject to different regulations and taxation 
depending on whether they are offered by investment companies, pre-
need companies, insurance companies, or bank trust departments.   
 
High  taxes  on  secondary  market  transactions  in  debt  and  equity 
securities  have  particularly  impeded  the  development  of  efficient 
secondary markets, while taxing initial public offerings (IPOs) of listed 
stocks and closed-end investment funds has made capital mobilization 
through the stock exchange less attractive to corporate issuers and 
investors. In this environment, the domestic financial market has not 
been an effective mechanism for savings mobilization. The result is 
overreliance on external borrowings to meet both public and private 
sectors’ financing requirements.  
 
  In  the  current  economic  environment,  one  of  the  more  difficult 
  challenges facing the Philippines is to create a foundation for the NBF 
    sector to enable it to provide essential financial services needed to 
mobilize the supply of funds for business investment. To meet this 
challenge, it will require comprehensive legal, regulatory, and policy 
reforms  to  develop  a  more  efficient  and  competitive  NBF  sector; 
reduced market and product segmentation; improved governance and 
risk management practices; and greater uniformity in the regulatory and 
prudential  standards  applicable  to  the  NBF  sector  and  investment 
products.  These  reforms  will  take  time  to  adopt  and  have  to  be 
implemented in sequences to ensure effectiveness.  
 
The first Nonbank Financial Governance (NBFG) program1 addressed 
(i) governance of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC); (ii) 
modernizing the governance and regulatory structure of the Philippines 
Stock  Exchange  (PSE);  (iii)  strengthening  market  oversight, 
compliance, and enforcement of SEC; and (iv) facilitating diversification 
and innovation in corporate financing. Building on reforms under NBFG, 
four areas of weaknesses need to be further addressed urgently to 
pave the way for the recovery of the NBF sector. These areas include  
(i) weak and fragmented regulatory structure and policy; (ii) supervisory 
and surveillance capacities of SEC, the regulatory agency; (iii) financial 
information and disclosure and prudential standards for NBFIs; and (iv) 
overreliance on banks to mobilize savings.

      Objectives and   The Program was formulated based on Objectives and Principles of 
Scope  Securities  Regulation  of  the  International  Organization  of  Securities 
  Commission (IOSCO), the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) ongoing 
  assistance in the sector, and the Mission’s findings. The goal of SNFG 
    is to promote the development of the nonbank financial sector by (i) 
  strengthening the regulatory and policy framework for developing viable 
  institutions and properly functioning financial markets; (ii) continuing to 
  strengthen  SEC’s  enforcement  capacities,  supervisory  skills,  and 
  practices; (iii) improving transparency to protect investors from fraud, 
  insolvency,  or  misconduct;  and  (iv)  facilitating  the  mobilization  of 
  domestic savings to increase supplies of funds while ensuring investor 
  protection. 
   
  To achieve these objectives, SNFG will seek to (i) establish an effective 
  anti-money laundering regime; (ii) strengthen investor protection and 
  confidence  in  PSE;  (iii)  remove  policy  distortions  and  address  the 
  fragmented  regulatory  framework  to  promote  market  efficiency  and 
  development; (iv) clearly define SEC supervisory responsibilities and 
  enhance  its  monitoring  and  surveillance  capacity;  (v)  improve  the 
  quality of financial information disclosed to the market; (vi) strengthen 
  prudential standards; and (vii) promote the development of collective 
  investment  vehicles  and  establish  a  proper  framework  for  investor 
  protection. As designed, the Program will move the Philippines to full 
compliance  with  all  of  IOSCO’s  30  Objectives  and  Principles  of 
Securities Regulation.

Risks and  One of the principal risks associated with the Program is the resistance 
Safeguards  of vested interests, particularly as the Program is politically sensitive 
and seeks to end money-laundering activities. To minimize the risks, 
the policy actions have been formulated to cover reforms that are within 
the  executive  branch  of  the  Government  to  implement.  The  more 
difficult  reforms  requiring  the  enactment  of  politically  sensitive 
legislation, including the passage of the amendments to the Anti-Money 
Laundering Act is included in the Program as a first tranche condition to 
prevent  the  possible  delayed  enactment  of  both  legislation  from 
affecting  the  implementation  of  other  significant  reforms  supported 
under  the  Program.    The  Government  has  shown  political  will  to 
implement  the  Program;  for  example,  despite  resistance,  the 
amendments to the Anti-money laundering law satisfactory to Financial 
Action  Task  Anti-Money  Laundering  were  passed  by  Congress  in 
March 2003. 
   
Apart from politically sensitive legislation, the Program will also impose 
significant  costs  to  the  private  sector,  particularly  as  firms  will  be 
required to adopt International Accounting Standards (IAS). While large 
accounting firms are likely to be able to more easily adopt the required 
changes, smaller firms will have greater difficulty and less resource for 
staff  retraining.  Likewise,  there  will  also  be  costs  to  all  companies 
registered with SEC as they will be required to change from Philippines 
General Accounting and Auditing Principles to IAS as their staff will 
have  to  be  retrained  to  meet  the  new  reporting  requirements.  The 
Program  recognizes  the  difficulty  and  costs,  associated  with  the 
changes and has made provision for the Government to adopt the new 
accounting  standards  gradually  until  2005.  While  the  transition  is 
relatively shorter than that in the European Union, the risks are deemed 
adequately  mitigated  as  the  Philippines  has  a  large  pool  of  well-
qualified  accountants,  making  the  transition  easier  than  in  many 
emerging markets.

iv   
   
Lastly with the Program calling for SEC to adopt risk-based capital 
standards for NBFIs, there will be significant costs to NBFIs to meet 
the  new  requirements.  A  large  number  of  NBFIs  are  likely  to  be 
required to raise their capital to match the risks on their balance sheet 
and  as  such  are  expected  to  strongly  object  to  the  reforms. 
Nevertheless, the objection is likely to be overcome as similar reforms 
have already been implemented in the banking sector. 
 
Technical  The objective of the proposed technical assistance (TA) is to (i) help the 
Assistance  Government  prepare  medium-  and  long-term  strategies  to  advance 
reforms  and  further  develop  the  NBF  sector,  and  (ii)  promote 
competition and remove impediments to the creation and distribution of 
innovative financial products and services. The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of the Philippines for the Second Nonbank Financial Governance (SNFG) 
Program. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Support for the 
Nonbank Financial Sector, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT1 
2.  Driven by a rebound  in external demand and strong domestic private consumption 
(supported by a steady inflow of remittances), the Philippine economy outperformed most of its 
neighbors in 2002 with the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growing by 4.6% year-on-year.2 
Inflation last year was 3.1%, which was well below the Government’s target of 4.5-5.5% due in 
part to the effects of a less accommodating monetary policy stance and milder-than-expected 
weather-related disruptions to agriculture and transport, and low food prices. Nevertheless, the 
low rate of inflation reflected continued excess industrial capacity in some sectors and high (and 
rising) unemployment. However, as the world economic recovery remains uncertain, particularly 
in the Philippines’ export markets of the United States (US) and Europe, the outlook of the 
Philippine economy is less robust over the short to medium term. Under the circumstances, 
GDP in 2003 is expected to grow more moderately, probably at a rate 4.0-4.5%. Despite a 
sharp rise in food prices in June, inflation should remain subdued in 2003 reflecting a negative 
output gap.  
 
3.  The  shortfalls  in  the  revenue  collection  system  weaken  the  Government’s  fiscal 
performance in 2002 and caused the budget deficit to widen to an estimated 5.3% of GDP 
against the original target of P130 billion or  3.3% of GDP. While difficulties with revenue 
collection are not a new problem in the Philippines, the recent and highly criticized public focus 
on this issue has strengthened the Government's resolve to undertake reforms in this area. 
Continued difficulties with fiscal management in the short run, however, are likely to exert 
upward  pressure  on  interest  rates—dampening  domestic  demand  and  macroeconomic 
stabilization efforts. 
 
4.  Despite the economy’s positive performance, growth has not been high enough to create 
more jobs for the rapidly growing labor force and unemployment continues to be high and rising.  
Higher levels of investment are necessary if the economy is to attain a higher growth path and 
unemployment is to be reduced.   
 
5.  The financial sector clearly has a central part to play in this effort through its role of 
channeling savings to productive investment to finance growth. Currently, however, the financial 
sector in the Philippines is bank-dominated and lending by the banking system to the corporate 
sector has been highly constrained by banks’ nonperforming loans (NPLs) that have steadily 
accumulated since the crisis. Latest estimates point to NPLs at above 15% of commercial 
banks’ total assets. The high level of NPLs within the banking system and overreliance of the 
corporate sector on bank lending are symptomatic of weak governance in the financial sector, 
and lack of alternative sources of financing to the banking system. Reforms to address these 
distortions  and  support  the  development  of  a  sound  nonbank  financial  (NBF)  sector  are

III.  THE SECTOR 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
1.  Regulation and Supervisory Framework 
 
7.  The NBF sector comprises the Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE)3 and a variety of 
financial intermediaries including investment houses, finance companies, broker-dealers firms, 
mutual funds, investment management companies, insurance companies, and pre-need plan 
companies. Pawnshops and lending investors providing loans to individuals, money changers, 
and money transmitters are also classified as nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs) in the 
Philippines (Appendix 1). 
 
8.  The  Securities  and  Exchange  Commission  (SEC)  is  the  main  regulator  of  NBFIs 
engaged in capital market activities. Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), the central bank, also 
regulates and supervises NBFIs that are subsidiaries of commercial banks and those with 
quasi-banking license, trust operations and foreign products and services, and pawnshops. SEC 
was established in 1936 under Commonwealth Act 83. In 1975, SEC was reorganized under 
Presidential Decree 902A into a quasi-judicial body with authority to investigate and prosecute 
fraud and other forms of misconduct, adjudicate corporate disputes, and interpret the laws 
administered by SEC. Under Decree 902A, SEC was also responsible for supervising the 
administration of insolvent companies. In 1982, under the Revised Securities Act, SEC was 
given authority to act as a securities regulatory body. In addition to acting as a securities 
regulatory body, SEC also serves as a registrar of companies, both publicly and privately held. 
 
9.  The Government promulgated the Securities Regulation Code (SRC) in 2000. The SRC 
superseded the Revised Securities Act and Presidential Degree 902A and has narrowed the 
mandate of SEC to regulation of the securities markets and enforcement. The new law allowed 
SEC to transfer its quasi-judicial function to courts. In addition, it provides SEC with greater 
autonomy, indemnification for its staff against lawsuits, and greater financial resources to meet 
SEC’s  new  mandate.  As  a  result  of  the  powers  granted  to  SEC,  no  domestic  or  foreign 
securities other than exempt securities may be offered to the public without being registered 
with SEC. Under the new law, SEC is allowed, however, to continue to maintain its function as a 
registrar of both public and private companies. SEC, as such, supervises, not only companies 
with publicly traded securities, but also all corporations, partnerships, and associations, which 
are required to register with SEC.  
 
10.  The SRC requires the demutualization of PSE in response to the inside trading scandal 
in  2000.  Additional  laws  governing  NBFIs  include  the  Corporation  Code,  the  Investment

11.  Insurance companies, on the other hand, are regulated and supervised by the Insurance

  2.  Recent Performance of the Capital Markets 
 
12.  Activities relating to the equity market are centered on PSE. The equity market, which 
peaked in 2000, has just begun to show signs of recovery after 2 years of sharp decline amid a 
difficult global economic environment. PSE’s market capitalization dipped to P2,083.2 trillion 
($46.4 billion) from its peak of P2.6 trillion ($58.8 billion) in 2000 and recovered to P2,493.8 
trillion ($46.4 billion) by 30 June 2003. As of today, PSE lists 233 companies. 
 
13.  The trading volume has been thin since 2000; from January to June 2003, 31.3 billion 
shares were traded, compared with 949 billion in 1999. Market turnover had fallen to just P40

earnings of PSE and NBFIs that rely on the equity trading volume as a major source of 
revenues. Consequently, PSE’s operating income fell from P324.4 million in 2000 to P160.4 
million in 2001, and to P159.5 million in 2002.4

15.  With a recurring budget deficit since 1998, the fixed income market in the Philippines 
consists largely of government debt instruments (treasury bills with tenors of 91, 182, and 364 
days and bonds with maturity of 2, 5, 7, 10, 20 and 25 years). Except for small-denomination

Although CPs account for a small fraction of the domestic debt market, they are more frequently

instruments. It is expected that the exchange will be opened for trading during the early part of 
2004. 
 
B.  Recent Reforms in the Nonbank Financial Sector  
16.  The enactment of SRC in 2000 was the cornerstone of the reforms in the NBF sector in 
the Philippines. To meet its new mandate under SRC, SEC reorganized itself and has built the

5
capacity of its staff, with assistance from ADB5 to strengthen regulation and enforcement. A new 
set  of  core  operating  departments,  including  market  regulation,  corporation  finance, 
enforcement, and compliance and inspection, has been established. SEC reorganized its staff 
and developed a full-scale training program in market surveillance and monitoring, enforcement, 
and  compliance  in  conformity  with  the  laws,  rules,  and  regulations  according  to  the  SEC 
mandate. With ADB assistance, SEC is also strengthening staff skills relating to a management 
information system (MIS) for better monitoring and surveillance of market participants. With the 
SRC provision allowing SEC to raise salary standards to attract qualified staff, SEC has been 
able to increasingly attract and retain qualified staff.   
 
17.  In 2002, SEC adopted the Code of Corporate Governance requiring all listed companies 
to have at least 20% of independent directors to represent the public and minority shareholders’ 
interests.  Recently,  SEC  sought  to  tighten  this  requirement  further  by  increasing  the 
independent directors from 20% or two independent directors whichever is lower, to 20% or two 
independent directors whichever is higher.  
18.   PSE has also undertaken a number of reforms. As a member-owned limited-liability 
company with objectives to provide services and minimize costs for its members rather than 
seek to maximize profits, PSE has used its operating surpluses to cover losses from any 
unlikely system failures, or to improve systems and facilities for market development, public 
awareness, and investor education. However, due to the inside trading scandal of BW shares in 
2000, PSE was criticized for being a cozy club of members that acted to protect the interest of 
its own members. To restore investors’ confidence in the market weakened by the BW scandal, 
PSE took steps to demutualize by transforming itself from a non-profit member organization into 
a for-profit stock corporation in 2001. Along with the change, PSE ownership of shares has 
since been separated from trading rights to allow the entry of new market players. Each of the 
184 members now owns 50,000 PSE shares and trading rights and is now allowed to sell 
his/her shares while retaining his/her trading rights. PSE’s governance has also been changed; 
the majority of the PSE board members is now nonbroker directors.   
19.   To improve its self-regulatory organization (SRO) structure, PSE has reconstituted its 
compliance and enforcement division and has strengthened its market monitoring systems with 
the implementing the electronic net capital reporting and monitoring system for brokers/dealers 
to permit daily monitoring. Moreover, PSE has adopted an on-line daily disclosure system to 
improve  the  transparency  of  listed  companies.  PSE  and  trading  participants  and  listed 
companies have also adopted the Corporate Governance Code and AML Guidelines. Trading 
participants and securities traders and salespeople have also since adopted a Code of Ethics 
and Code of Conduct and Ethics, respectively.6 PSE also launched its enhanced web site to 
provide  more  comprehensive  market  data,  stock  quotations,  dividend  declarations,  trading 
activities,  and  other  pertinent  information  on  the  exchange,  trading  participants,  listed 
companies, and other institutions.7

C.  Issues and Constraints 
20.   Despite the progress of the noted reforms, more has to be done to address policy and 
regulatory constraints that impede the development of the NBF sector. As is, the sector is small 
and underdeveloped (Table 2), accounting for just about 20% of the total assets in the financial

particularly impeded the development of efficient secondary markets, while taxing initial public

22.  In the current economic environment, one of the more difficult challenges facing the 
Philippines is to create a foundation for the NBF sector to enable it to provide essential financial 
services  needed  to  mobilize  the  supply  of  funds  for  business  investment.  To  meet  this 
challenge, comprehensive legal, regulatory, and policy reforms are required for a more efficient 
and competitive NBF sector, reduced market and product segmentation, improved governance 
and  risk  management  practices,  and  greater  uniformity  in  the  regulatory  and  prudential 
standards applied to the NBF sector and investment products. These reforms will take time to 
adopt and will have to be implemented in sequence or in phases to ensure effectiveness. 
Building on reforms under the nonbank financial governance program (NBFG), four areas of 
weaknesses will be addressed to pave the way for the recovery of the NBF sector: (i) weak and 
fragmented regulatory structure and policy; (ii) supervisory and surveillance capacities of the 
regulatory agency, SEC; (iii) financial information and disclosure and prudential standards for 
NBFIs; and (iv) continued overreliance on banks to mobilize savings. 
 
1.  Weak and Fragmented Regulatory and Policy Framework  
 
a.  List of Noncooperative Countries and Territories (NCCTs) 
 
23.  As early as the late 1990s, BSP introduced a number of measures to strengthen AML 
laws  and  procedures  based  on  its  existing  legislative  and  supervisory  authority.  These 
measures include prohibiting anonymous accounts and introducing customer identification and 
reporting requirements. Strict provisions under the Bank Secrecy Act, however, have prevented 
bank examiners from accessing customer account information. 
 
24.  As the second step toward establishing an effective AML regime, an AML law8 was 
enacted on 29 September 2001. Since proceeds from crime can be laundered through a wide 
variety of financial institutions, “covered institutions” under the law include all financial (bank and 
nonbank) institutions under the supervision of BSP, SEC, and IC. The law, however, allows a 
limited exception to the Bank Secrecy Act, requiring the “covered institutions” to report to the 
Anti-Money  Laundering  Council  (AMLC)  any  transaction  in  excess  of  P4,000,000  (about 
$75,000 at the current exchange rate). A subsequent assessment of the law by the Financial 
Action Task Force on Money Laundering’s (FATF), however, identified several deficiencies: (i) 
the threshold for suspicious transactions is too high to constitute a meaningful deterrent to 
money laundering (compared with the standard threshold norm of about $10,000); and (ii) 
provisions  in  the  law  hinder  rather  than  strengthen  the  Government’s  power  to  carry  out 
effective investigations.   
 
25.  The Philippines, consequently, has been included  on the FATF list of NCCTs and had to 
enact  amendments  to  the  AML  law  satisfactory  to  the  FATF  by  March  2003  to  avoid 
countermeasures. Additionally, it will have substantially complied with other recommendations 
concerning effective measures to combat money laundering activities to be removed from the 
FATF list of NCCTs.

26.  Under SRC, PSE is required to be demutualized with no single group of shareholders 
owning more than 20% of PSE, and no single individual or entity owning more than 5%. As 
indicated earlier, PSE has been corporatized through conversion into a shareholding corporate

nonmembers,  or  independent  external  directors.  However,  it  has  yet  to  achieve  the  SRC 
mandate of divestiture. 
   
c.  Unfavorable Policy Environment 
 
27.  Taxes  are  identified  as  one  of  the  major  factors  impeding  market  efficiency  and 
development  of  the  NBF  sector.  There  is  no  capital  gains  tax  on  listed  equity  securities; 
however, there is a 10% value-added tax on the brokerage commission. Moreover, all shares 
and stock certificates are subject to a stamp duty tax of 1.0% and all debt instruments to a 
range of 0.3-1.5% documentary stamp tax (DST), depending on the type of instrument (i.e., 
debentures or CPs). For deposits in commercial banks, however, the DST is not applied across 
the board. Only time deposits (with a minimum of P50,000) are subject to the DST; other 
deposits such as those in special accounts (with a minimum of P300,000) are DST exempt.    
 
28.  More importantly, when traded, both debt and equity instruments are subject to an 
additional DST on the buyer and a stock transaction tax on the seller, which, combined, add 
1.25% to the transaction cost.  Failure to attach the stamp will make the document unacceptable 
in third party transactions and cannot be used as evidence in court. A major drawback of the 
DST is the application of the tax every time the instrument changes hand; the more time the 
financial instruments are traded, the higher the costs to the investors. The cascading feature of 
the DST discourages the trading of financial instruments and market development and, as such, 
reduces liquidity in the secondary markets, not only for debts but also for equity instruments.9 
 
29.  The  tax  revenue  from  the  secondary  trading  of  equity  instruments  varies  with  the 
performance  of  the  equity  market,  ranging  from  about  P400  million  to  about  P1.4  billion 
annually, while that from secondary trading of debt instruments is estimated to range from P200 
million to P500 million. The tax revenue collected from DST on debt and equity instruments 
represent less than 1% of the aggregate revenue. However, as DST is a relatively more reliable 
source of revenue and convenient to collect, it is very difficult for the Government to eliminate it.  
  
30.   Aside from the DST, equity securities listed on PSE, including closed-end funds, are 
subject to an initial public offering (IPO) tax of 2-4% depending on the float available to public 
shareholders. The IPO tax makes it more costly than it should be for business to raise needed 
capital for investment and reduces the Philippines’ ability to compete for issuers particularly in 
light of growing competition among the stock exchanges within the region. 
 
31.  It is recognized that the NBF sector, like any other sector in the economy, should pay its 
share of tax revenue; however, taxation should minimize the distortions in the financial markets. 
The above taxes, combined, have reduced the efficiency of financial markets and have made 
alternative sources to bank financing too costly.

32.  As  indicated  earlier,  the  NBF  sector  and  capital  market  are  underdeveloped  and 
fragmented in the Philippines. As a result, the capital market has not been an effective mechanism 
for domestic capital mobilization. It is also not well prepared to compete in the evolving regional 
and global financial markets. Nevertheless, the SRC recognizes the importance of promoting the 
development of the capital market along with the need to protect investors and eliminate practices 
that create distortions in the market. To achieve the goals contemplated in SRC 2000, it is crucial 
that SEC carefully assess and address the economic impact of regulatory policy, market structure, 
and taxation issues on the operations and efficiency of the capital markets and fully develop the 
medium-term framework for the NBF sector into a comprehensive long-term strategy to develop 
the NBF sector.  
 
2.  SEC Supervisory and Surveillance Capacities  
33.  As indicated earlier, the SRC has made SEC a more enforcement-oriented, operationally 
independent regulator with clear objectives and procedure. However, SEC needs to continue to 
work  on  enhancing  the  enforcement  skills  of  its  staff  to  ensure  effective  regulation  and 
enforcement. Moreover, its electronic information management capacity needs to be further 
enhanced  to  have  updated  information  readily  available  for  inspection,  investigation,  and 
surveillance. 
 
34.  While regulatory and supervisory authority over NBFIs should be clearly defined, joint 
inspection should also be encouraged where necessary. In the Philippines, three Government 
organizations are responsible for regulating and supervising NBFIs; (i) SEC, (ii) BSP, and (iii) 
IC. In 1999, BSP and SEC entered into an agreement on the exercise of regulatory and 
supervisory authority over NBFIs (with the exception of insurance companies, which traditionally 
have come exclusively under the domain of IC). Under the agreement BSP is responsible for 
supervising investment houses and other subsidiaries and affiliates of universal banks, which 
are also registered with SEC to perform capital market activities such as underwriting. As BSP 
is moving toward consolidated supervision, which will result in a reorganization and merger of 
the  bank  and  nonbank  supervision  departments,  in  conjunction  with  building  an  effective 
consolidated supervisory framework, it would be highly desirable to amend the agreement 
between BSP and SEC to provide for joint inspection by BSP and SEC. Joint inspection of the 
investment house and securities broker and dealer subsidiaries or affiliates of banks is essential 
to avoid potential gaps arising from separate on-site inspections and to allow the use of SEC’s 
expertise. 
 
3.  Move to Strengthen Transparency and Prudential Regulations 
35.  To improve the quality of financial information and disclosure, the Government has 
gradually moved away from the Philippines General Accounting and Auditing Principles (GAAP) 
and has phased in the adoption of auditing and accounting standards based on international 
auditing and accounting standards since 2001, with a target of completing adoption by 2004 and 
2005,  respectively.  Nevertheless,  other  standards  to  ensure  investor  protection  from  fraud, 
insolvency, or misconduct, including prudential, fit and proper standards, and a basic element of 
self-regulation should be established and/or further strengthened.   
 
36.  First, securities broker-dealers and investment houses are subject to inconsistent capital 
requirements. Brokers and dealers in securities are subject to SEC’s net capital rule. The rule is 
largely risk-based and derived from the US SEC uniform net capital rule. Investment houses, on 
the other hand, are subject to capital standards defined under the implementing guidelines of

10  
BSP.10 More importantly, capital requirements for all types of NBFIs are not sufficiently calibrated to 
the risks they are assuming, nor do they provide sufficient early warning in the event an NBFI 
encounters financial distress that might lead to insolvency. As such, the capital standards should 
be revised and harmonized according to risks. In particular, NBFIs’ risks in securities and similar 
instruments held in inventory have to be well calibrated and harmonized with respect to both 
market and credit risks. There should also be a tiering of initial capital requirements (i.e., entry 
requirements) depending on the nature of the risks undertaken and the types of licenses obtained 
(i.e., broker, dealer, underwriter, and/or full service securities market intermediary or investment 
house). Lastly, ongoing risk-based capital standards should be in harmony with those advocated 
by  International  Organization  of  Securities  Commission  (IOSCO)  for  securities  market 
intermediaries.    
 
37.  Second, fit and proper standards are specifically defined in the Banking Act of 2000 but are 
not included in the SRC or the Insurance Law. While these standards—which allow SEC to 
prescribe, pass upon, and review the qualifications and disqualifications of appointed individuals 
or elected directors and officers and to disqualify those found unfit to serve—are essential for 
regulating NBFIs and conform to international best practice, SEC and IC currently do not have 
sufficient authority to adopt them. Third, all members of PSE are required to have a designated 
compliance  officer  but  nonmembers  who  are  also  registered  with  SEC  to  engage  in 
underwriting, government securities business, or investment advisor activities do not have a 
similar requirement. Compliance is the most important element of regulation or self-regulation, 
as it begins at the individual firm level. It is the first line of defense in an effective regulatory 
scheme.  It  would  be  highly  desirable  for  NBFIs  to  designate  a  compliance  officer  who  is 
required to serve in an advisory capacity with responsibility to develop the procedures and 
capacity to comply with applicable rules and regulations. 
 
4.  Savings Mobilization to Increase the Supply of Investment Funds  
 
38.  Among  the  three forms  of  collective  investment  vehicle  marketed  to  the  public—(i) 
common trust funds (CTFs) managed by banks, (ii) mutual funds managed by investment 
companies, and (iii) pre-need schemes managed by authorized pre-need plan companies—the 
last two are constrained by the absence of a conducive policy and regulatory framework that will 
adequately protect investors and provide a more conducive environment for both industries to 
grow. This constraint has impeded the more effective mobilization of domestic savings for 
financing business investment.    
 
a.  Pre-Need Plans 
39.  The pre-need industry, which provides benefits relating to education, pension funds 
accumulation, interment and death-related services, has grown an average of 25% annually 
over the past 15 years. Since 1977, about 6 million plans have been sold and the industry’s total 
assets of P160 billion are now greater than the assets of the life insurance companies, nearly 
twice as much as CTF assets, and nearly 15 times as much as mutual funds net assets. In 
recent years, however, the economic environment has been adverse to the successful operation 
of the pre-need industry. With few investment alternatives, the pre-need investment portfolio has 
been invested mainly in (i) Treasury bills and government bonds, (ii) bank deposits, (iii) real-
estate, and (iv) listed stocks. Following the recent experience in global financial markets, returns 
on investments in both debt and equity instruments have been low relative to earlier time

September 2002. Nevertheless, it seems likely that at least one major pre-need company will 
have to go through some form of resolution in 2003, particularly if necessary prudential and 
consumer rights regulations are introduced. In addition, a number of trust funds are unlikely to 
be able to comply with a newly imposed limit on real property holdings. 
 
 41.  Despite the industry’s rapid growth and recent financial difficulty, there has yet to be a 
law specifically governing the pre-need companies. Recently, the basic sales practices and 
governance of the pre-need industry have been questioned. Regulation, up to now, has been 
left to SEC to establish through the issuance of rules and circulars. As the real estate market is 
not expected to recover significantly and help improve the financial conditions of pre-need 
companies over the near term, there is an urgent need to enhance the monitoring of the 
financial and operational condition of the pre-need sector and to increase the frequency of on-
site inspections and compliance to ensure that the industry is solvent and plan -holders are 
protected.   
 
b.  Investment Companies/Mutual Funds  
 
42.  Mutual funds are operated under the Investment Company Act (ICA) passed in the late 
1950s. The ICA is based on the US Investment Company Act of 1940, during which time nearly all 
US investment companies were closed-end. Since then, the mutual fund and securities businesses 
have undergone significant changes. Today the dominant form of investment- company is open-
end mutual funds and the regulatory regime has shifted from “merit regulation” to “full disclosure.” 
As the ICA was enacted primarily as a response to industry scandals over 40 years ago, it is 
obsolete with provisions that are overly restrictive by international standards. For example, one 
provision  that  requires  all  board  members  of  investment  companies  to  be  Filipino  citizens 
effectively prevents foreign participation in investment companies organized in the Philippines. The 
minimum paid-up capital requirement under the ICA is as small as P500,000. Moreover, under the

D.  ADB Operations and Lessons Learned   
  
44.  As one of the two major development partners in the NBF sector,12 ADB has been 
supporting  the  Government  with  both  program  loans  and  technical  assistance  to  advance 
reforms  in  the  sector.  Two  loans  were  provided  for  the  sector:  (i)  the  Capital  Market 
Development Program (CMDP) loan,13 and (ii) Nonbank Financial Governance Program (NBFG) 
loan (footnote 4). Through this assistance, ADB has established and maintained a strong and 
constructive policy dialogue with the Government in support of the development of the sector.  
 
45.  The  CMDP,  approved  in  August  1995,  focused  on  (i)  consolidating  the  two  stock 
exchanges,  (ii)  encouraging  transparency  and  accountability  through  increased  public 
disclosure of financial information, and (iii) building capacity and market confidence. The second 
tranche of the loan was scheduled for release in December 1997 but, as a result of delays in 
compliance, the loan was closed in December 1999 and the second tranche cancelled. The 
pending conditions of the CMDP were linked to the passage of the Securities Act of 1999 (now 
referred to as the SRC) and the RICA. Due to the delayed passage of legislation, program 
implementation was initially rated as unsatisfactory. Another factor that delayed implementation 
is the number of reforms attached to one piece of legislation. The SRC contains conditions and 
amendments that were required to fulfill 21 of the 49 policy actions identified in the CMDP. 
Subsequent enactment of the SRC, initiated under the CMDP, resulted in the rating being 
changed to partially successful in the program completion report. 
 
46.  Despite implementation delays, the CMDP lays the foundation for the reform under 
NBFG with the enactment of the SRC. Based on the SRC and its implementing rules and 
regulations, NBFG could advance reforms focusing on four areas: (i) restructuring SEC as a 
result  of  the  enactment  of  the  SRC  in  2000  and  strengthening  SEC’s  monitoring  and 
enforcement capacity; (ii) modernizing of the governance and regulatory structure of PSE; (iii) 
strengthening market oversight, compliance, and enforcement; and (iv) facilitating diversification 
and innovation in corporate financing. As NBFG was designed as a program loan with only one 
tranche, all policy conditions under NBFG were fully complied with prior to loan effectiveness 
and release.  
 
47.  To date none of the adopted reforms under NBFG has been reversed.  With its scope of 
responsibilities  significantly  narrowed  under  the  SRC,  SEC  is  now  able  to focus more  on 
enforcement of securities laws and regulation. SEC fully reorganized itself in 2000 and has 
since gradually built its capacity and upgraded its computer system and MIS to meet its new

not  extend  to  ensuring  timely  enactment  by  an  independent  branch  of  Government.  The

The result was a protracted deliberation period. Congressional elections in May 1998 further

changes—be  implemented  before  the  loan  is  critical  and  is  an  important  indicator  of  the

loans for the Philippines, the second nonbank financial governance (SNFG) is designed to 
ensure  that  the  risks  for  noncompliance  are  minimized;  more  difficult  policy  conditions, 
particularly the passage of politically sensitive amendments to anti-money laundering act, are 
front-loaded; and the proposed reform program supported by ADB was discussed with relevant 
stakeholders, including the legislative branch of the Government. 
 
IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Objectives and Scope 
50.  The proposed reform program under the SNFG is formulated as a continuation of the 
program  supported  under  the  NBFG (Appendix  3)  to  address  the  policy,  institutional,  and 
regulatory  weaknesses  identified  earlier.  The  Program  was  formulated  based  on  IOSCO’s 
Objectives and Principles of Securities Regulation, ADB’s ongoing assistance in the sector, and 
the Mission’s findings. The objective of SNFG is to promote the development of the NBF sector 
by (i) strengthening the regulatory and policy framework for developing viable institutions and 
properly  functioning  financial  markets;  (ii)  continuing  to  strengthen  SEC’s  enforcement 
capacities, supervisory skills, and practices; (iii) improving transparency to protect investors 
from fraud, insolvency, or misconduct and (iv) facilitating the mobilization of domestic savings to 
increase supplies of funds while ensuring investor protection. The program framework is in 
Appendix 4. 
 
51.  To achieve these objectives, the Program will seek to (i) establish an effective AML 
regime, (ii) strengthen investor protection and confidence in PSE, (iii) remove policy distortions 
and  address  the  fragmented  regulatory  framework  to  promote  market  efficiency  and 
development, (iv) clearly define SEC supervisory responsibilities and enhance its monitoring 
and  surveillance  capacity,  (v)  improve  the  quality  of  financial  information  disclosed  to  the

14  
market, (vi) strengthen prudential standards, and (vii) promote the development of collective 
investment vehicles and establish the proper framework for investor protection. As designed, 
the Program would move the Philippines to full compliance with all IOSCO’s 30 Objectives and 
Principles of Securities Regulation. 
           
B.  Program Framework and Actions 
52.  During the preparation of NBFG in 2001, four agenda for policy dialogue were proposed 
for the second phase of the reform program: (i) implementing demutualization of PSE; (ii) 
strengthening market regulation; (iii) strengthening market governance and compliance; and (iv) 
facilitating  diversification  and  innovation  in  corporate  financing  (Appendix  3).  Although  the 
objective of SNFG and the direction of the Program remain broadly in line with those suggested 
under NBFG, its scope has been modified, enhanced, and expanded to include three additional 
components, namely, (i) establishing an effective AML regime, (ii) strengthening prudential 
standards for NBFIs, and (iii) promoting the development of collective investment vehicles. 
Besides the three new components, a number of critical policy measures are added to enhance 
the program content. These measures include (i) removing DST on secondary securities trading 
and the IPO tax to increase liquidity in the capital markets and encourage listing, and (ii) rules 
intended to further strengthen disclosure and prohibit actions designed to improperly influence 
auditors and so prevent accounting and corporate misconduct as recently evident in the US. 
  
53.  Some  of  the  agenda  suggested  in  2001—demutualization  of  PSE,  increasing 
transparency in clearing and settlement of securities and depository functions, amending tax 
laws to promote the development of the insurance industry, and establishing the fixed income 
trading counter—have been modified or excluded to reflect the current market condition and the 
Government’s  priorities,  and  to  rearrange  the  sequencing  of  reforms  relating  to  the 
establishment of the fixed income exchange. As a step toward demutualization, SNFG supports 
SEC’s call for PSE to develop a business plan to broaden ownership of the exchange as 
mandated  under  the  new  SRC  by  (i)  completing  its  asset  evaluation  as  preparation  for 
divestiture, (ii)  developing  a  strategy  to  achieve  self-financing,  and (iii)  appointing majority 
nonmember directors to PSE’s selected board committees. The change in governance has 
already taken place in PSE. Among other things, the majority of the board members is now 
nonbrokers and a nonbroker chairs its audit committee. This change will weaken the control of 
the members and increase an incentive for members not to hold on to their shares. Since the 
equity market has begun to show signs of recovery since the end of May after a 2-year period of 
sharp decline and the prospect of recovery will continue to remain uncertain, it is considered 
more appropriate for SNFG to allow flexibility on the timing of divestiture. Nevertheless, SEC 
and ADB will continue to monitor the progress of PSE’s demutualization.  
 
54.  As for increased, transparency in clearing and settlement of securities and depository 
functions, scripless trading has already been implemented by the Philippines Depository and 
Clearing Inc. (PDCI). If the fixed -income exchange is established as anticipated, PDCI plans to 
provide settlement of securities and depository functions solely for fixed income trading. PSE, 
on the other hand, is in the process of buying its own settlement and clearing system for its 
trading activities. The new clearing and settlement system is in line with international norms, 
and settlement and clearance procedures at both PDCI (after the establishment of the fixed-
income exchange) and PSE will be subject to SEC regulations and approval.       
 
55.  While promoting the development of the insurance industry is an element of the policy 
reforms the Government would like to pursue, however, other legislation with more pressing 
policy agenda—rationalization of the DST, amendments to the AML law and pre-need code—

15
have and will occupy most of the 2003 and 2004 legislative agenda of the Government. As 
such, it was decided that it would be more effective to address this issue in future ADB 
assistance. Lastly, the Program excludes the establishment of the fixed income exchange 
strictly because the exchange will be established by the private sector and the more active 
trading of debt instruments is expected to happen once the DST on securities secondary trading

56.  The Program is linked to NBFG by directly building on the foundation established by 
administrative reforms under NBFG and technical assistance provided by ADB. As noted in 
paras. 16 and 17, reforms under NBFG, combined with ADB technical assistance, helped 
establish  some  preconditions  for  effective  securities  regulation  by  restructuring  SEC  and

surveillance capacity, and lay the groundwork for PSE’s divestiture, while encouraging PSE to 
strengthen its SRO structure.  More importantly, as SEC is now in a better position to more 
effectively monitor compliance with securities market rules and regulations, the Program will (i) 
address  more  difficult  policy  and  regulatory  weaknesses  relating  to  taxation,  prudential 
regulations  for  both  pre-need  and  mutual  funds  industries;  and  (ii)  strengthen  financial 
disclosure and auditing requirements to ensure more effective savings mobilization and investor 
protection to mitigate systematic risk in the financial system.  
 
57.  The  Program  with  specific time  bound policy  actions  proposed for  the  SNFG  is  in

1.  Strengthening the Regulatory and Policy Framework for Developing Viable 
Institutions and Properly Functioning Financial Markets 
 
a.  Establishing an Effective Anti-Money Laundering Regime 
58.  The Philippines has been included in the FATF list of NCCT. As a fundamental step 
toward establishment of an effective AML regime, an AML law (Republic Act 9160) was enacted 
on 29 September 2001. A subsequent assessment of the law by FATF, however, identified 
deficiencies, notably that the threshold for suspicious transactions was too high to constitute a 
deterrent  to  money  laundering.  To  address  this  problem,  the  Government  promulgated 
implementing rules and regulations (IRRs) that attempt to address some of the deficiencies 
cited by FATF, but recognized that the law had to be amended to adequately meet international 
norms.  Underscoring its commitment to establish an effective AML regime, the Government 
prepared draft amendments to the law and  worked with Congress to enact early in 2003 
legislation that is satisfactory to FATF.  
 
59.  Establishing an adequate legal framework is, however, only the first step in developing 
an effective AML regime. An institutional structure will have to be created and institutional 
capacity built to effectively implement the law. Developing an AML institutional structure in the 
Philippines has involved the creation of the Anti-Money Laundering Council (AMLC) as the lead 
agency in this area. It will also involve designating special AML courts and formulating and 
formalizing the various interinstitutional relationships needed to make a functioning AML regime. 
 
60.  Developing adequate institutional capacity to implement the law, on the other hand, will 
require significant resources including technical support.  Specialized capacity will have to be 
built across a wide range of institutions to implement the law effectively. Support will need to be

16  
particularly intensive in the case of AMLC, where prior operational experience does not exist 
domestically. A successful outcome will require the sustained involvement and support of a wide 
range of government agencies, industry associations, and other constituencies. 
 
61.  To establish an effective AML regime, the Program supports (i) the development of a 
robust  legal  framework  that  meets  international  norms,  and  (ii)  the  establishment  of  an 
institutional structure and strengthening of institutional capacity, including that of AMLC and 
other agencies involved in implementing the law. An effective AML regime is fundamental to 
strengthening investor confidence and will provide the Government with key tools in its fight 
against graft and corruption. ADB technical assistance on AML14 has helped AMLC achieve this 
objective.  
 
b.  Strengthening  Investor  Protection  and  Confidence  in  the  Stock 
Exchange 
 
62.  The Program calls for PSE to continue strengthening its own corporate governance by 
including more nonmembers in its key committees under the board of directors. An exchange, 
governed by a board with a majority of nonbroker representatives and an ownership structure 
whereby no single group of stakeholders can dominate the exchange, can be expected to act in 
the public interest to the extent that good corporate governance can be achieved while striving 
to maximize profits for the benefit of shareholders. 
  
63.  There is an urgent need for PSE to invest in new technology to upgrade its trading and 
market surveillance capability to improve efficiency and strengthen investor confidence. The 
Program supports PSE’s initiative to develop a divestiture strategy to dilute brokers’ ownership, 
and to make the exchange attractive to investors (other than brokers).  
 
64.  To improve PSE governance, not only in the majority of its board members nonbrokers, 
PSE’s audit committee is now chaired by a nonmember. To dilute the ownership of members, 
PSE will list its shares by introduction in August 2003 and is planning to sell shares to the public 
in 2004. SEC and ADB will continue to monitor the progress of PSE’s demutualization. The 
Program also supports SEC’s call for PSE to develop an effective business plan, among other 
things, to address its self-regulatory responsibilities. The plan should include a discussion of 
PSE’s examination program, compliance with exchange and SEC rules, market surveillance 
capacity, proposed penalties for violating exchange rules, and PSE committees’ performance of 
SRO functions. A sound business plan in respect to the performance of SRO functions under 
the oversight of SEC is crucial investor protection. The plan will balance the interest of the 
investing public with the profit maximization interest of shareholders. Although SEC should not 
engage in merit regulation with respect to IPOs, to ensure public confidence in the exchange, 
SEC will review and approve the business plan, given PSE’s unique role as a SRO. 
 
c.  Removing Policy Distortions and Addressing a Weak Regulatory 
Framework to Promote Market Efficiency and Development 
65.  To increase liquidity in the capital markets and facilitate the development of domestic 
debt markets, the Program supports the Government’s move to work closely with Congress to 
enact legislation to rationalize the DST on securities instruments and remove the DST on the 
second trading of debt and equity instruments, including closed-end funds, and stock lending 
and borrowing transactions. As removing the DST on secondary trading would incur substantive

2.  Further Strengthening SEC Supervisory and Surveillance Capacity 
      
68.  To further strengthen SEC’s supervisory and surveillance capacity to meet the principles 
and objectives of IOSCO, the Program calls for SEC to upgrade its MIS to enable it to gather 
and  analyze  databases  for  monitoring  and  surveillance  purposes.  With  ADB  technical 
assistance, SEC is training its own staff in market surveillance, enforcement, and compliance in 
line with its new mandate under the SRC.  
 
69.  To avoid potential gaps in separate on-site inspections and to allow the use of SEC’s 
expertise in respect to capital market transactions and underwriting activities, the Program also 
recommends that SEC and BSP amend a memorandum of understanding between BSP and 
SEC to (i) provide an action plan and procedures for joint on-site inspections of dually regulated 
entities to minimize cost of supervision, while ensuring that regulatory gaps do not occur; and (ii) 
standardize the regulatory and operational reports filed with BSP and SEC. Furthermore, SEC is 
encouraged to review and update its existing inspection procedures and allow for SEC-PSE 
joint on-site examination of PSE member brokers and dealers on a sample basis or in respect to 
cause or thematic examinations.

3.  Improving Transparency to Protect Investors from Fraud, Insolvency, or 
Misconduct 
 
70.  International best practices in regulation and governance emphasize that information 
disclosure and transparency are important so that investors, counterparties to transactions, and 
other stakeholders can evaluate the financial conditions of a regulated financial institution as an 
added  safeguard  to  supplement  those  provided  by  government  oversight  in  the  form  of 
prudential standards, on-site inspections, and off-site monitoring of financial and operational 
reports. The Program calls for SEC to phase -in on its web site the public disclosure of annual 
audited financial information for all registered NBFIs for public viewing. Currently, all SEC 
registered NBFIs are required to file with SEC an annual audited financial statement, which is 
available for public inspection.  SEC performs the corporate registration function, but it does not 
maintain a full service branch office network whereby investors could view public documents 
filed with SEC.  
 
71.  The Program supports the Government’s undertaking to move away from Philippines 
GAAP to International Accounting Standards (IAS). All public companies registered with SEC 
are required to comply with IAS rather than with the Philippines GAAP by 2005.  Accordingly, 
there is a need to train accounting professionals and auditors in the use of IAS. With ongoing 
ADB  assistance,15  the  SEC  with  the  Board  of  Accountancy  (BOA)  is  implementing  a 
comprehensive training program for adopting IAS.  
 
72.  In light of the recent accounting scandal in the US, there is now renewed emphasis in 
both developed and emerging financial markets on the need to reform auditing practices and to 
promote  stronger  corporate  governance  in  selecting  and  retaining  of  external  independent 
auditors  for  listed  companies.  The  Program  intends  to  improve  the  quality  of  disclosed 
information  and  to  raise  public  confidence  by  strengthening  financial  disclosure  and  audit 
practices. It specially calls for SEC to issue a regulation requiring the chief executive officer and 
chief financial officer of listed companies, or persons performing similar functions, to disclose to 
the issuer’s auditors and to the audit committee of the board of directors (i) all significant 
deficiencies in the design or operation of internal controls that could adversely affect its ability to 
record, process, and report financial data; and (ii) any fraud that involves management or other 
employees who have a significant role in internal controls.  
 
73.  Effective January 2003, SEC will take effective disciplinary actions— including revoking 
the accreditation of noncompliant auditors—against issuers and other NBFIs or auditors for 
significant violation of established accounting standards and rules. In addition, the Program 
recommends that Board of Accountancy, which is responsible for establishing auditing and 
accounting  standards  in  the  Philippines,  to  adopt  the  code  of  ethics  in  harmony  with 
international best practice such as that of the International Federation of Accountants. The 
Program also recommends that SEC require all listed companies to rotate auditors at least once 
every 5 years to ensure independent and quality audits.

4.  Strengthening Prudential Standards for NBFIs 
 
a.  Risk-Based Capital Standards 
 
74.  The  Program  recommends  that  the  capital  requirements  of  investments  houses, 
government securities dealers, and securities brokers and dealers be risk-based and in harmony 
with international best practices, taking into account position risk for all dealer activities of securities 
market intermediaries engaged in trading and investment, market-making, and/or firm commitment 
underwriting. Under IOSCO's best practice framework, capital standards for securities market 
intermediaries (i.e., brokers, dealers, and underwriters) take the following form: (i) liquidity and 
solvency should be covered; (ii) mark-to-market principles should be employed; and (iii) risk-based 
requirements should cover all risks of the firm, and, in particular should contain (a) a base 
requirement reflecting the scale of a firm's activities to capture nonmeasurable risks; (b) position 
risk requirements reflecting price volatility of individual securities, with provisions for concentrated 
positions and allowance for risk reduction measures such as hedging; and (c) settlement of 
counterparty risk requirements reflecting the risk of nonperformance in a timely manner.  
 
b.  Fit and Proper Standards 
 
75.   The Program calls for SEC to submit to Congress amendments to the SRC to enable 
SEC to establish “fit and proper” standards for officers and directors of regulated entities (i.e., 
broker-dealers, listed companies, investment companies, investment advisors), comparable with 
those in the Banking Act whereby SEC will be able to prescribe, pass upon, and review the 
qualifications and disqualifications of appointed individuals or elected directors or officers, and 
disqualify those found unfit to serve. 
c.  Certification of Compliance Officer 
 
76.  The Program recommends that all securities brokers and dealers, investment houses, 
finance  companies,  and  investment  companies  be  required  to  have  a  compliance  officer 
certified by examination to ensure understanding of applicable laws and regulations, including 
prudential standards, financial and operational reports required by the regulator, sales practices, 
and other safeguards to protect investors. This requirement is crucial as the compliance officer 
will have a major responsibility for preventing, detecting, and resolving problems before they 
rise to the level of rules violations. To have an effective compliance program, the Program calls 
for SEC, together with BSP, to develop and implement a training and certification program for 
compliance officers.  
 
5.  Facilitating  Mobilization  of  Domestic  Savings  to  Increase  Supplies  of 
Investment Funds While Ensuring Investor Protection 
 
77.  To  facilitate  mobilization  of  domestic  savings  and  ensure  investor  protection,  the 
Program focuses on supporting the pre-needs and mutual funds industries. 
 
         a.  Pre-Need Plans 
 
78.  To ensure plan holder protection and the solvency of pre-need companies, the Program 
first calls for the Government to submit the proposed pre-need code to Congress for approval. 
To strengthen public confidence and minimize losses to plan holders in the event of insolvency, 
the proposed code would provide a broad mandate to the regulator of pre-need plans to

20  
establish  an  investor  protection  scheme  with  the  details  of  fund  operation  and  coverage 
determined by the regulator for the protection of pre-need policy-holders. Given that pre-need 
products partake of the nature of insurance products, the proposed code would transfer the 
regulatory and supervisory function of the industry from SEC to IC. Meanwhile, to ensure plan 
holders’ protection, the Program stresses that SEC should order pre-need plan companies that 
fail to comply with the SEC regulation on trust fund deficits to cease or desist from selling new 
plans.  
 
79.  Second, the Program recommends that industry sales practices must be reviewed and 
advertising practices brought under closer supervisory control issuing more comprehensive 
regulatory guidelines on advertising.  The Program stresses a regulatory review of advertising, 
either by the government regulator or through the creation of an SRO for the pre-need sector.  
The  Program  also  calls  for  the  supervisory  agency  of  the  pre-need  companies  to  issue 
comprehensive  guidelines  on  pre-need  advertisement  and  announce  that  it  will  conduct 
thorough on-site, unscheduled inspections of pre-need companies at least once every 3 years.   
 
80.  Third, the Program recommends that the supervisory agency strengthen the role of 
independent  directors  in  pre-need  companies  given  the  importance  of  public  trust  in  the 
industry. In addition, the Program calls for the regulatory agency to develop an examination and 
certification program for an officer designated as compliance officer. The compliance officer 
must be knowledgeable in the laws and regulations and compliance applicable to pre-need 
companies and have a sound knowledge of best practices in corporate governance and the 
fiduciary obligations of the pre-need company and trustee to the plan holders.     
 
 b.  Mutual Funds 
 
81.  The Program supports the Government’s move to submit the RICA for enactment to 
replace the outdated ICA. Among other things, the RICA would allow greater competition and 
greater market entry by removing the requirement that all board directors for mutual funds must 
be  Filipinos;  raising  the  minimum  paid-up  capital  requirement  for  mutual  fund  companies 
significantly to ensure that only financially viable companies can engage in the business, which 
depends on maintenance of public confidence; establishing investment standards for mutual 
funds to avoid potential conflicts of interest and abuses; and increasing penalties for violating 
certain provisions. 
  
82.  The Program stresses that corporate governance of investment companies must also be 
improved by  strengthening the fiduciary  obligations of the  board  of directors  with  respect to 
management and the performance of quasi-regulatory self-policing functions. The Program also 
calls for SEC to require that a majority of the board of directors be independent directors within 2 
years of the enactment of the RICA, and to strengthen corporate governance by requiring that at 
least one officer or director pass an examination related to operational and regulatory compliance, 
including applying rules and regulations for safekeeping and valuation of fund assets. Significant 
related party transactions, as defined by SEC, which management proposes to enter into should 
also require the approval of shareholders.

VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
93.  The Program will help promote the development of the NBF sector by strengthening

spread of systemic risks in the financial sector. By strengthening the regulatory and policy

6.  Business Risk Factors.  For investment companies, three types of risk are apparent:  (i) 
market risk, liquidity risk, and operational risk. Emerging markets are volatile and sometimes 
illiquid. Nevertheless, the net asset value of the fund must be computed each day. The method of 
computing earnings and asset values must be fair and correct and in compliance with SEC 
regulations. The mutual fund also has an obligation to accurately value net assets and promptly

become increasingly difficult to meet investors' demands for redemption unless efforts are made

exposure to the mutual funds. Finally, there are operational risks associated with the safekeeping 
of funds and securities held in custody for the benefit of shareholders. With regard to risk 
management and investor protection, the board of directors has important fiduciary obligations to 
fund shareholders. The fund must be managed for the benefit of the shareholders in accordance 
with the objectives disclosed to investors in the fund's registration statement.

B.  The Pre-Need Industry 
13.  The pre-need industry in the Philippines, which provides benefits relating to education, 
pension funds accumulation, interment and death-related services, has grown remarkably since 
its  inception  in  1966.  The  industry  has  now  become  one  of  the  most  significant  savings 
mobilizers in the Philippines. Since 1977, nearly 161 million plans have been sold. From 1990 to 
2001, pre-need annual sales grew at an average rate of 25%. Throughout the past decade, 
pension and education plans have been the largest selling products of the industry and have 
been the factor sustaining the overall growth of pre-need product sales. In absolute terms, 
sales of life and memorial plans have remained unchanged; however, in relative terms, they 
have been shrinking in size. Given its remarkable growth, the pre-need industry’s assets in the 
Philippines  totaled  P159.8  billion  in  2001,  compared  with  the  P147.5  billion  assets  of the 
insurance industry, P82 billion of the common trust fund, and P11.5 billion of mutual fund net 
assets. In 2002, however, sales of the pre-need companies dropped by 2.3% partly as the 
industry’s poor performance weakened plan holder confidence. 
 
14.  The pre-need industry—by sales value or size of assets—is highly concentrated. From 
1991 to 2001, over 60% and 80% of the total industry’s sales were made by the top 5 and top 
10  pre-need  companies  (by  asset  size),  respectively.  For  industry-wide  profitability,  sales 
growth has not been accompanied by high profit margins. The net profit margin was roughly 
constant at around 4.6% throughout 1999-2001. During this period, about two- thirds of pre-
need companies registered positive profit figures.  
 
15.  Pre-Need Plans. Pre-need plans are contracts that specify commitment of the pre-need 
companies to provide specified benefits to the plan holder or the plan holder’s beneficiary on a 
scheduled date agreed upon at inception. In return, the plan holder is required to pay the pre-need 
company in cash or on installment as specified in the contract. Three types of pre-need plans are 
offered to plan holders: education, pensions, and life or memorial plans. As education plans 
provide plan holder beneficiaries with a given stream of income, spread along a certain time 
period,  to  meet  educational  costs;  and  pension  plans  provide  predictable  income  flow  on 
beneficiaries’ retirement, they are also referred to as scheduled benefit plans. Life or memorial 
plans, on the other hand, are referred to as a contingent benefit plan as the timing of benefits 
depends on the occurrence of a contingency.

The  Government  of the  Philippines  is committed  to  promoting  sustainable  economic
growth  and development  and to enhance the well being of the Filipino people.  To achieve this
policy  goal,  the  Government  intends  to deepen  reforms  in all areas of the economy,  with the
focus  on  addressing  structural  constraints  that  have  resulted  in  domestic  and  external
imbalances.  The Government  is furthering  reforms in the financial sector.  The Government  has
embarked  reforms  for the past three years for the non-bank  financial  sector, knowing  that this
sector  is operating  in an environment  where  policies,  laws  and regulations  are  competitively
disadvantaged  and  its  development  stunted.  Nevertheless,  further. reforms  are  needed  to
develop  the sector in order to benefit from  integration in the regional and global capital markets
over the medium and long-term.
With  support  from the Asian  Development  Bank (ADB), the Government  launched the
Nonbank  Financial  Governance  (NBFG)  Program  in  2001.  The  reform  program  under  the
NBFG  focused  largely  on four  following  areas:  (i)  the  restructuring  of  the  Securities  and
Exchange  Commission  (SEC) as a result of the enactment  of the Securities  Regulations  Code
(SRC) in 2000 and the strengthening  of the SEC's monitoring  and enforcement  capacity; (ii) the
modernization  of the  governance  and regulatory structure  of the Philippines  Stock  Exchange
(PSE);  (iii) strengthening  market  oversight.  compliance  and  enforcement;  and  (iv) facilitating
diversification  and innovation in corporate financing.
Progress  has  been  made  in these  four  areas.  With  the  scope  of  the  SEC's
responsibilities,  under  the SRC, focusing  more on regulation. and enforcement,  SEC has fully
reorganized  in  2000  and  has since  gradually  built  its  capacity  and  upgraded  its  computer
system  to meet the SRC mandate.  Indeed, with the SRC allowing  provisions  for the SEC to
raise  salary  standards  to attract  qualified  staff, the  SEC  is now increasingly  attracting  new
graduates  trained  in both finance and law.  On the other hand, PSE's equity ownership  by the
brokers  still exceeds  the ceiling set by the SRC for an industry  and business group.  However,
the majority  of PSE's Board of Directors IS now made up of independent directors.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in the Philippines 
 
The financial sector plays a powerful, through indirect role in reducing poverty by facilitating long-term economic 
growth.  Growth, however, is turbulent and not necessarily pro-poor.  Growth entails change, which the poor may 
often not be well-equipped to cope with.  A well-governed financial sector that facilitates competition can help make 
growth user-friendlier (i) improving access to savings, credit, and insurance instruments, which enable the poor to 
cushion shocks as well as take advantage of opportunities created by change; and (ii) allowing for better terms on 
those instruments. 
A well-governed financial sector also reduces the likelihood and severity of financial and economic crises and 
consequently helps safeguard against a corresponding marked increase in the incidence of poverty.  Balanced 
financial sector development can promote financial system stability and strengthening by allowing risks to be more 
evenly spread among types of financial institutions and spurring competition between them.  The financial sector in 
the Philippines is currently bank-dominated and heavily unbalanced in its structural composition.  Development of a 
sound nonbank financial sector is key to providing effective alternate means of corporate finance as well as 
strengthening overall financial sector integrity.

Analysis: 
Job creation has not kept pace with the growth of the labor force and unemployment continues to be high and rising.  
Higher levels of investment are necessary if the economy is to attain a higher growth path and unemployment is to be 
reduced.   
 
The financial sector clearly has a central part to play in this effort through its role in channeling savings to productive 
investment to finance growth. Currently, however, the financial sector in the Philippines is bank-dominated and 
lending by the banking system to the corporate sector has been highly constrained by nonperforming loans (NPLs) 
that have steadily accumulated since the crisis (latest estimates point to NPLs at above 15% of commercial banks’ 
total assets). The high level of NPLs within the banking system and overreliance of the corporate sector on bank 
lending are symptomatic of poor lending, weak governance in the financial sector, and lack of alternative sources of 
financing to the banking system. The need for reforms to address these distortions and support the development of a 
sound nonbank financial sector is fundamental if the financial sector is to act as a facilitator of rather than a constraint 
to long-term economic growth. 
 
Investment has also been significantly hindered by weak investor sentiment due in part to chronic and widespread 
graft and corruption. The Government's efforts establishing an effective anti-money laundering regime, represent an 
important step forward in addressing this problem, as an effective regime has the potential to serve as a key tool in 
tackling graft and corruption.
